title: Christina A. Buelow
text:
Github
  
  
    
     Publications
  
  
    
     Email
  



I’m a quantitative ecologist solving challenging problems related to conservation and sustainable use of Earth’s ecosystems. I use models - spatial, statistical, mathematical - to provide a robust evidence-base for decision-makers faced with difficult choices, such as how to set scientifically-sound targets for mangrove and seagrass conservation. To engage and inform end-users I develop web tools, e.g., this tool for exploring data related to conservation of the world’s Blue Forest ecosystems.
Find out more on the Research and Outreach & Teaching pages.
Currently, I’m a Research Fellow with the Global Wetlands Project at Griffith University.
Get in touch.

title: Projects
text:
Conservation Theories of Change
Description placeholder

title: Research
text:
How can we know where ecosystems, such as mangroves, are likely to adapt or be lost in the future? We need this information so that we can choose the right places to prioritise conservation and restoration efforts. However, useful forecasts of ecosystem change can be challenging to make the global scale, particularly with coarse datasets that are unable to capture processes operating at fine spatial scales.
In collaboration with the World Wildlife Fund, we’re developing novel approaches for forecasting the future of mangroves at the global scale when data of fine spatio-temporal resolution is limited.

title: Research
text:
Conservation Theories of Change
‘Theories of Change’ are a tool for planning conservation strategies, and define how actions will lead to desired socio-ecological outcomes. Theories of Change could be made more robust through explicit integration of enabling conditions, and via more rigorous testing and adaptation with causal theory and ecosystem models. I’m interested in using models and validation techniques to make global-scale mapping of conservation priorities and their Theories of Change more robust. I’m lucky to collaborate with a diverse team of experts, including environmental lawyers, to do so.

title: Outreach & Teaching
text: I’m an active organising committee member for the Geospatial Community. We run virtual workshops to learn techniques in spatial data science.

title: Outreach & Teaching
text: I’m an active organising committee member for the Geospatial Community. We run virtual workshops to learn techniques in spatial data science.

title: Outreach & Teaching
text:
Programming
I enjoy teaching and, in addition to tutoring and guest lecturing, I have developed and taught tutorials in spatial data science programming such as this intro to R spatial and this intro to RShiny. Watch the youtube recording of the workshop here.
I also help teach quantitative methods in the R programming language in an annual 5-day workshop, sign up for the next event in February 2024.

title: Tools
text:
Blue Forest Data Explorer
This app was built through a series of end-user engagement workshops to inform the World Wildlife Fund’s Blue Forest Initiative’s 10-year conservation strategy.

Enabling profiles for operationalising global Theories of Change
Explore enabling profiles for coastal wetland conservation and case-study Theories of Change.

Mapping and modelling mangrove futures in a changing climate
Explore historical and future climatic and anthropogenic impacts to mangroves, and what this means for future losses and gains in extent.

Set ambitious targets for mangrove and seagrass recovery
This tool allows end-users to set global conservation targets and estimate the rates at which countries will need to protect and restore to achieve them.

Find the code for these tools and their models here
